description: After buying a stock each of those automatically gernerates money in a specific time interval.
The player kinda has to babysit the stocks and click on them or upgrades to buy them. Especially after a reset the game starts anew just with higher multipliers.
The money is directly reinvested and therefore a consumable.
The player has to manage his own time and how he spends it most efficiently to maximize the output.
Each player can accuse every other player of being an imposter.

An direction inficator with the general direction is shown when
- an emergency must be fixed
- a task has multiple components
- in the hide and seek gamemode
Finding contradictions in the storys or actions of other players is an important game element.
The players explore the map and what is happening on it.
The player can customize the appearance of its character.
Each round some players are given the role of the imposter while they must roleplay as a crewmember.
The game does have minigames that force the players to move around, but the tasks itself are rarely complex.
Each imposter has a set of skills, which are unuseable for a set amount of time after use. Therefore the imposter must manage its use.
Each crewmember has a limited amount of emergency meeting buttons.
Since the imposter reduces the number of crewmembers with increasing round length, each crewmember must manage the time spend well.
Attacking or not attacking a crewmember as imposter is non trivial, neither is accusing another participant of being an imposter.

In some minigames the player needs to order stuff.
For accusing another player the player needs to connect the dots.

Since there is no way to write down information, the player needs to remember everything the other players do or say. This is an important part of the game experience, since it might be difficult to remember or talk about everything that happend.
Since the players do roleplaying and are hiding their real intentions social deduction can be used to find the truth.
A player can plan each round how he want to win it. As an imposter a specific strategy might be to wait in one room for targets or focus on using wents to escape.

Even though the player builds the buildings, processing the resources is done automatically without the users input.
Additionally the game allows the player to define tradingroutes.
The game has money and resources that can be used to build or buy stuff.
The game has ships and soldiers that need to be managed and directed.
Weather and quests are randomly appearing events. The world is also randomly generated.
The player might plan ahead when selecting an island, expanding or structuring his city.
Stones can be removed in a way, that connecting ones are disappearing automatically.
In the beginning of the game the number of stones that the player has available is limited. Hindering the player to progress at some points.
The game has jumping platforms and doors that can close.
Some riddles need you to plan ahead and think about how to solve them in regards to time and space.
In some cases the game indicates a solution which isnt one, or might suggest that a path is blocked, while in reality it is only a matter of perspective.
The player can electrocute enemies in water or set them on fire.
Some weapons shoot bullets that rikoschett
After testing and seeing which parts of the bridge need to be adjusted, the red indicators are not continuously shown. This requires the player to remember which parts need to be replaced.

The player must try different keywords to search for new videos, this might lead to dead ends when the keyword is not used in any video or when the player only finds already explored videos.
videos that were not yet seen by the player are marked with a yellow eye icon
anti-glare filter to remove the pc monitor look
The game contains a minigame (in the trash bin).
a map of all database entries discovered

Even though the game provides a query history it does not provide a tool to mark query that the player wants to perform in the future. possible new query words must either be saved as a tag or on a sheet on real world paper.
The player can select video clips and add them to a session.
Even though the amount of widgets is limited the player can move these around a place them like on a usual operating system.

the game is not completely up to the definition of first person, since it is like the player is the computer screen, but it is similar. Also the face of the investigator (the player) is sometimes reflected in the pc screen.
Investigating and understanding the timeline is an elemental component to the game, since the videos are ordered by time while you can only see the first 5 clips.
the player must listen but also observe closely to get clues for new query words - e.g. water and coffee
The player must understand what the suspect is saying, this including contextual information and interpretation.
The game explains its features via an ingame text and video tutorial.
Board where information can be connected via red strings.
The player has limited inventory space.
The game has money for example as a reward for solving cases.
The game can plot a route indicating the direction via an arrow.
investigating crime scenes and similar
The game gives you various options how to proceed in your investigation. For example when opening doors, you can try to find a key, break in or use brute force.

You can get information by talking to npcs.
The player must answer questions regarding the murder case, which is difficult due to the space of possible suspects.
There are multiple was to solve a case and also multiple ways to investigate it.
The game might present you with options that lead to nothing like dead ends.
The game has specific rules that can be learned to ease the investigation resulting in more ways to solve a case.

The game saves a lot of information for the player, this information is predefined. This is the case for the detective notebook (image) as well as the screen with the wires. As described the saved infomation might be overriden.
indoor map with predefined symbols e.g. for cameras
the city, building and floors can be explored

The player must apply the rules of the game to let people pass or deny them.
Each round new rules need to be learned to succeed in the game.
The game is played from a first person perspective but without the camera moving. The screen is divided into multiple areas providing different perspectives.
The game send you error messages if you decided wrong and also presents newspapers.
The player can hide different types of information on the screen and customize his workspace. The player can for example show and hide a map on demand and position it freely.
The player has money that is rare and needs to be used to feed his family.
The player has only a limited amount of time each round (day), so making the most of it is important since the player gets paid for each citizen processed.
The player must choose if he lets specific citizens pass even though it is against the rules. This can have bad outcomes for the player but can also be benificial.
The game has a story which the player can directly influence.
The game presents its content in a queue which needs to be processed.
The player needs to be fast in some instances reacting quickly enough to prevent bad outcomes.

The player might need to remember rules for himself. Even though the game provides sufficient material to research rules that where forgotten, it is faster to know which rules currently apply instead of researching them each time anew.
In some situations the player is forced to enact violence.
first person view
The complete game is based on time, being able to travel to different stages of the crews history.
The player can hover over characters in the picture allowing him to get a close up image.
Using the clock and a corpse the player can jump to different key points in time, rewatching sequences that occured.
The player must choose the name and the fate of each passenger, choosing from a big variety of possibilities.
The player must observe and rule out possible solutions for each passenger for example when finding the correct name.
Explore the ship and the temporal events that happend to the crew. Find new clues and story pieces.
When choosen a certain number of fates correctly the game confirms these choices.
The player can note the name and fate of each passenger in the logbook even if the player is not yet certain. Essentially making an educated guess.
The bits of information that the player obtains must be remembered by the player himself.
The game has bookmarks.
Since monst of the passengers die the player is experiencing violence.
Every riddle has one solution and in most cases only one way to solve it.
Bring number in the correct order.
logic challenges
Each stage has special symbols adding new rules to the levels.
The game has an endless mode in which the level are randomly generated.
The game has an endless mode in which the level can be random generated.
No guessing
highlighting lines, also allowing to see crossings
Hide line indicators that are not needed anymore.
Every puzzle has one valid solution.
Explore each puzzle by revealing different cells after each other.
Minecraft has a gameplay element hat is similar to real life electricity allowing the player to reconstruct complex systems and build fully automated machines.
The player can construct complex machinery from the ground up.
The player has complete control over every part of his build machines and can fully customize the speed and each action the machine does.
Minecraft has a text chat.

Due to the ability to harvest and place blocks everywhere it is possible to build structures with those blocks. In these cases it is not uncommon to layout the structure using very common blocks without actually starting the actual building. Essentially using blocks as placeholder.
The game is completely procedural generated and therefore random and almost unlimited in size. This allows the player to explore areas with a multitude of bioms and animal wildlife.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the first person view.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the spectator mode.
The game allows the player to alter the color of beds and sheep as well as selecting different skins for the playercharacter or changing the texturepack altogether.

Since blocks are a valuable resource to build structures it is not uncommon for players to grind them for example to obtain glas. Other scenarios are rare minerals that need to be mined which is timeconsuming or farming monsters for experience points. All of these scenarios are often done even if the player already has enough resources.
The player can place signs with free text (but limited space) or even write books, saving important information.
The player can place signs on blocks to tag them as something. Another example would be placing blocks above chests to essentially tag the contents of them.
The player can drop items and blocks which stay in the gameworld for a limited amount of time, other players could then collect these items for them self.
Using the functionality of the map, which just shows the most top block at each coordinate it is possible to draw whole pictures by placing blocks on specific positions.
In one mode the player regularly has to consume food to stay alive, this food need to be farmed and obtained. Other examples are rare minerals that allow for trading.
Using player placed portals, the player can travel long distances in a short amount of time.
The game has certain gameobjects and blocks that react to physics, like water, sand and pressure plates.
Using flags the player can place symbols on his map to indicate important locations.
The world is randomly generated and monster do spawn randomly.
Multiple objects in the world can be combined (crafted) to more advanced versions. These combinations require a crafting recipe for example rare ores can be combined to form tools.

Depending on the playstyle player might need to remember different things. Stating with the crafting recipes, other informations are where the players base is located or where the player saw an interesting cave.
The player can write on signs or in books. This text can be read by other players allowing to share or save important information.
The player can change the view to a third person camera.
The player can beat monsters and animals and even player vs player fight can occur.

The game is played from a first person perspective but without the camera moving. The screen is divided into multiple areas providing different perspectives.
The game send you error messages if you decided wrong and also presents newspapers.
players can hide different types of information on the screen and customize his workspace, e.g. they can show/hide a map on demand
The player has money that is rare and needs to be used to feed his family.
The player has only a limited amount of time each round (day), so making the most of it is important since the player gets paid for each citizen processed.
The player must choose if he lets specific citizens pass even though it is against the rules. This can have bad outcomes for the player but can also be benificial.
The game has a story which the player can directly influence.
The game presents its content in a queue which needs to be processed.
The player needs to be fast in some instances reacting quickly enough to prevent bad outcomes.

The player might need to remember rules for himself. Even though the game provides sufficient material to research rules that where forgotten, it is faster to know which rules currently apply instead of researching them each time anew.
In some situations the player is forced to enact violence.
first person view
The complete game is based on time, being able to travel to different stages of the crews history.
The player can hover over characters in the picture allowing him to get a close up image.
Using the clock and a corpse the player can jump to different key points in time, rewatching sequences that occured.
The player must choose the name and the fate of each passenger, choosing from a big variety of possibilities.
The player must observe and rule out possible solutions for each passenger for example when finding the correct name.
Explore the ship and the temporal events that happend to the crew. Find new clues and story pieces.
When choosen a certain number of fates correctly the game confirms these choices.
The player can note the name and fate of each passenger in the logbook even if the player is not yet certain. Essentially making an educated guess.
The bits of information that the player obtains must be remembered by the player himself.
The game has bookmarks.
Since monst of the passengers die the player is experiencing violence.
Every riddle has one solution and in most cases only one way to solve it.
players must make sure all conditions are satisfied
logic challenges

The game has an endless mode in which the level are randomly generated.

Minecraft has a gameplay element hat is similar to real life electricity allowing the player to reconstruct complex systems and build fully automated machines.
The player can construct complex machinery from the ground up.
The player has complete control over every part of his build machines and can fully customize the speed and each action the machine does.
Minecraft has a text chat.

Due to the ability to harvest and place blocks everywhere it is possible to build structures with those blocks. In these cases it is not uncommon to layout the structure using very common blocks without actually starting the actual building. Essentially using blocks as placeholder.
The game is completely procedural generated and therefore random and almost unlimited in size. This allows the player to explore areas with a multitude of bioms and animal wildlife.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the first person view.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the spectator mode.
The game allows the player to alter the color of beds and sheep as well as selecting different skins for the playercharacter or changing the texturepack altogether.

Since blocks are a valuable resource to build structures it is not uncommon for players to grind them for example to obtain glas. Other scenarios are rare minerals that need to be mined which is timeconsuming or farming monsters for experience points. All of these scenarios are often done even if the player already has enough resources.
The player can place signs with free text (but limited space) or even write books, saving important information.
The player can place signs on blocks to tag them as something. Another example would be placing blocks above chests to essentially tag the contents of them.
The player can drop items and blocks which stay in the gameworld for a limited amount of time, other players could then collect these items for them self.
Using the functionality of the map, which just shows the most top block at each coordinate it is possible to draw whole pictures by placing blocks on specific positions.
In one mode the player regularly has to consume food to stay alive, this food need to be farmed and obtained. Other examples are rare minerals that allow for trading.
Using player placed portals, the player can travel long distances in a short amount of time.
The game has certain gameobjects and blocks that react to physics, like water, sand and pressure plates.
Using flags the player can place symbols on his map to indicate important locations.
The world is randomly generated, monsters spawn randomly and loot is generated from loot tables.
Multiple objects in the world can be combined (crafted) to more advanced versions. These combinations require a crafting recipe for example rare ores can be combined to form tools.

Depending on the playstyle player might need to remember different things. Stating with the crafting recipes, other informations are where the players base is located or where the player saw an interesting cave.
The player can write on signs or in books. This text can be read by other players allowing to share or save important information.
The player can change the view to a third person camera.
The player can beat monsters and animals and even player vs player fight can occur.

Each round some players are given the role of the imposter while they must roleplay as a crewmember.
The game does have minigames that force the players to move around, but the tasks itself are rarely complex.
Each imposter has a set of skills, which are unuseable for a set amount of time after use. Therefore the imposter must manage its use.
Each crewmember has a limited amount of emergency meeting buttons.
Since the imposter reduces the number of crewmembers with increasing round length, each crewmember must manage the time spend well.
Attacking or not attacking a crewmember as imposter is non trivial, neither is accusing another participant of being an imposter.

Minecraft has a gameplay element hat is similar to real life electricity allowing the player to reconstruct complex systems and build fully automated machines.
The player can construct complex machinery from the ground up.
The player has complete control over every part of his build machines and can fully customize the speed and each action the machine does.
Minecraft has a text chat.

Due to the ability to harvest and place blocks everywhere it is possible to build structures with those blocks. In these cases it is not uncommon to layout the structure using very common blocks without actually starting the actual building. Essentially using blocks as placeholder.
The game is completely procedural generated and therefore random and almost unlimited in size. This allows the player to explore areas with a multitude of bioms and animal wildlife.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the first person view.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the spectator mode.
The game allows the player to alter the color of beds and sheep as well as selecting different skins for the playercharacter or changing the texturepack altogether.

Since blocks are a valuable resource to build structures it is not uncommon for players to grind them for example to obtain glas. Other scenarios are rare minerals that need to be mined which is timeconsuming or farming monsters for experience points. All of these scenarios are often done even if the player already has enough resources.
The player can place signs with free text (but limited space) or even write books, saving important information.
The player can place signs on blocks to tag them as something. Another example would be placing blocks above chests to essentially tag the contents of them.
The player can drop items and blocks which stay in the gameworld for a limited amount of time, other players could then collect these items for them self.
Using the functionality of the map, which just shows the most top block at each coordinate it is possible to draw whole pictures by placing blocks on specific positions.
In one mode the player regularly has to consume food to stay alive, this food need to be farmed and obtained. Other examples are rare minerals that allow for trading.
Using player placed portals, the player can travel long distances in a short amount of time.
The game has certain gameobjects and blocks that react to physics, like water, sand and pressure plates.
Using flags the player can place symbols on his map to indicate important locations.
The world is randomly generated, monsters spawn randomly and loot is generated from loot tables.
Multiple objects in the world can be combined (crafted) to more advanced versions. These combinations require a crafting recipe for example rare ores can be combined to form tools.

Depending on the playstyle player might need to remember different things. Stating with the crafting recipes, other informations are where the players base is located or where the player saw an interesting cave.
The player can write on signs or in books. This text can be read by other players allowing to share or save important information.
The player can change the view to a third person camera.
The player can beat monsters and animals and even player vs player fight can occur.

After buying a stock each of those automatically gernerates money in a specific time interval.
The player kinda has to babysit the stocks and click on them or upgrades to buy them. Especially after a reset the game starts anew just with higher multipliers.
The money is directly reinvested and therefore a consumable.
The player has to manage his own time and how he spends it most efficiently to maximize the output.
Each player can accuse every other player of being an imposter.

An direction inficator with the general direction is shown when
- an emergency must be fixed
- a task has multiple components
- in the hide and seek gamemode
Finding contradictions in the storys or actions of other players is an important game element.
The players explore the map and what is happening on it.
The player can customize the appearance of its character.
Each round some players are given the role of the imposter while they must roleplay as a crewmember.
The game does have minigames that force the players to move around, but the tasks itself are rarely complex.
Each imposter has a set of skills, which are unuseable for a set amount of time after use. Therefore the imposter must manage its use.
Each crewmember has a limited amount of emergency meeting buttons.
Since the imposter reduces the number of crewmembers with increasing round length, each crewmember must manage the time spend well.
Attacking or not attacking a crewmember as imposter is non trivial, neither is accusing another participant of being an imposter.

In some minigames the player needs to order stuff.
For accusing another player the player needs to connect the dots.

Minecraft has a gameplay element hat is similar to real life electricity allowing the player to reconstruct complex systems and build fully automated machines.
The player can construct complex machinery from the ground up.
The player has complete control over every part of his build machines and can fully customize the speed and each action the machine does.
Minecraft has a text chat.

Due to the ability to harvest and place blocks everywhere it is possible to build structures with those blocks. In these cases it is not uncommon to layout the structure using very common blocks without actually starting the actual building. Essentially using blocks as placeholder.
The game is completely procedural generated and therefore random and almost unlimited in size. This allows the player to explore areas with a multitude of bioms and animal wildlife.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the first person view.
Minecraft has multiple camera modes, one of which being the spectator mode.
The game allows the player to alter the color of beds and sheep as well as selecting different skins for the playercharacter or changing the texturepack altogether.

Since blocks are a valuable resource to build structures it is not uncommon for players to grind them for example to obtain glas. Other scenarios are rare minerals that need to be mined which is timeconsuming or farming monsters for experience points. All of these scenarios are often done even if the player already has enough resources.
The player can place signs with free text (but limited space) or even write books, saving important information.
The player can place signs on blocks to tag them as something. Another example would be placing blocks above chests to essentially tag the contents of them.
The player can drop items and blocks which stay in the gameworld for a limited amount of time, other players could then collect these items for them self.
Using the functionality of the map, which just shows the most top block at each coordinate it is possible to draw whole pictures by placing blocks on specific positions.
In one mode the player regularly has to consume food to stay alive, this food need to be farmed and obtained. Other examples are rare minerals that allow for trading.
Using player placed portals, the player can travel long distances in a short amount of time.
The game has certain gameobjects and blocks that react to physics, like water, sand and pressure plates.
Using flags the player can place symbols on his map to indicate important locations.
The world is randomly generated, monsters spawn randomly and loot is generated from loot tables.
Multiple objects in the world can be combined (crafted) to more advanced versions. These combinations require a crafting recipe for example rare ores can be combined to form tools.

Depending on the playstyle player might need to remember different things. Stating with the crafting recipes, other informations are where the players base is located or where the player saw an interesting cave.
